title: Woodworking — Hammering Nails into Soft Wood
description: Introduction to woodworking. The child learns to hold a hammer, position a nail, and drive it into a piece of soft wood (balsa or pine). This builds hand strength, coordination, and confidence with real tools.
instructions:
1. 'Today we use a real hammer and real nails! Woodworking is an important skill.'
2. Safety rules: 'Hold the hammer near the end of the handle. Keep your other hand clear of the nail once you start hammering. Always hammer on the work surface.'
3. Demonstrate: hold the nail near the top, tap it gently to set it in the wood.
4. Once the nail stands on its own, move fingers away. Hammer with firm, controlled taps.
5. 'Your turn! Set the nail first with light taps. Then hammer it in.'
6. Practice driving 4-5 nails into the wood block.
7. Optional: hammer nails in a pattern (straight line, circle, letter).
materials_needed: Soft wood block (balsa, pine, or cork)

slides.setup_instructions: Clamp the wood block to a sturdy table. Put on safety goggles. Lay out hammer and nails. Draw dots on the wood where nails should go.

slides.text: 'Today you learn to use a REAL hammer! Woodworkers build furniture, houses, and all sorts of things. First, safety: put on your goggles.'
'Hold the hammer near the END of the handle — that gives you more power. Hold the nail near the TOP with your other hand. Tap GENTLY to set it in the wood.'
Demonstrate: set the nail with 2-3 gentle taps until it stands on its own. 'Now move your fingers AWAY. Hammer with firm, steady taps until the nail is in the wood.'
'Your turn! Pick a spot with a dot. Hold the nail, tap to set it, move your fingers, and hammer it in. Take your time — accuracy matters more than speed.'

slides.prompt: Hammer 4-5 nails into the wood block. Try to follow the dots. Can you make a straight line of nails? A letter? A shape?

slides.text: Put the hammer back in its place. Remove goggles. 'You used a real tool like a real builder! What would you like to build someday?'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child safely set and drive a nail into soft wood with controlled hammer strikes?

parent_notes: Woodworking is an authentic Montessori practical life activity that builds tremendous confidence. Children are capable of using real tools with proper instruction and supervision. Large-headed roofing nails are safest because the child is less likely to miss. Soft wood (balsa, pine, or thick cork) requires less force. Always clamp the wood to a stable surface — the child needs both hands free. Safety goggles are non-negotiable. Start with just hammering nails straight in; later lessons will add sanding, drilling, and simple construction. The concentration and hand-eye coordination required rival any fine motor exercise. Many children find the rhythmic hammering deeply satisfying. This work gives real competence with real tools — a core Montessori principle.

title: Grammar — The Article (Montessori Grammar Symbols)
description: Introduction to the Montessori grammar symbol for the article. The child learns that 'the,' 'a,' and 'an' are special small words called articles that come before nouns, represented by a small light blue triangle.
instructions:
1. 'You know the puzzle words the and a. Today we learn what kind of words they are!'
2. 'Words like the, a, and an are called ARTICLES. They come before a naming word.'
3. Show the Montessori grammar symbol: small light blue triangle.
4. 'The article is a tiny triangle because it is a small but important word that points to the noun.'
5. Read sentences on strips. Find the articles. Place the light blue triangle above each one.
6. 'The cat sat. A dog ran. An egg fell.' Child places triangles above the, a, an.
7. Child writes or builds sentences and marks articles with the symbol.
materials_needed: Montessori grammar symbols (light blue triangle for article)

slides.heading: Grammar
slides.subheading: The Article — Small Light Blue Triangle

slides.setup_instructions: Prepare sentence strips with clear articles. Have multiple small light blue triangles ready (cut from paper or use Montessori grammar symbols).

slides.text: 'You know the words THE, A, and AN. These tiny words have a special name — they are called ARTICLES. An article comes before a thing word.'
'In Montessori, every type of word has a symbol. The article's symbol is a small LIGHT BLUE TRIANGLE.' Show the symbol. 'It is small because articles are small words!'
Read a sentence strip: 'THE cat sat on A mat.' 'Find the articles! THE is an article. A is an article.' Place light blue triangles above each.
'AN is also an article. We use AN before words that start with a vowel sound: AN apple, AN egg, AN orange.'

slides.prompt: Read each sentence strip. Find every article (the, a, an). Place the light blue triangle symbol above it. How many articles can you find?

slides.text: 'Articles are small words with a big job — they introduce the noun! THE dog, A tree, AN island. You will see them everywhere now.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify articles in sentences and place the correct grammar symbol above them?

parent_notes: Montessori grammar uses visual symbols to make parts of speech concrete and memorable. Each part of speech has a unique shape and color. The article is a small light blue triangle — small because it is a minor word, triangular because in Montessori tradition all noun family words (noun, article, adjective) are triangles. The child is not expected to memorize grammar rules — they learn through physical manipulation (placing symbols) and pattern recognition. Articles are taught before adjectives because the child already knows 'the' and 'a' as puzzle words. This simply gives those familiar words a grammatical identity. You can cut triangles from light blue card stock or use commercial Montessori grammar symbols.

title: Stamp Game — Multiplication
description: The child uses the stamp game for multiplication, building the same number multiple times and combining. This transfers the golden bead multiplication concept to the more abstract stamp material.
instructions:
1. 'We multiplied with golden beads and bead bars. Now let us multiply with the stamp game!'
2. Problem: 213 taken 3 times.
3. 'Build 213 three times — three separate rows of stamps.'
4. Row 1: 2 hundreds, 1 ten, 3 units. Row 2: same. Row 3: same.
5. 'Now combine! Units: 3+3+3=9. Tens: 1+1+1=3. Hundreds: 2+2+2=6.'
6. Read the answer: 639.
7. Practice: 124 x 3, 231 x 2, 312 x 3. Exchange when needed.

slides.setup_instructions: Set up stamp game on the mat. Prepare multiplication problems using 3-digit numbers times 2, 3, or 4.

slides.text: 'Multiplication means taking the same number several times. Let us do 213 taken 3 times with stamps!'
'Build 213 in the first row: 2 red hundreds, 1 blue ten, 3 green units. Now build 213 again in a second row. And again in a third row.'
'Three rows of 213! Now combine. Start with units: 3 + 3 + 3 = 9 units. Tens: 1 + 1 + 1 = 3 tens. Hundreds: 2 + 2 + 2 = 6 hundreds.'
'The answer is 639! 213 taken 3 times equals 639.' Record it. 'What if we get more than 9 in one category? We exchange!'

slides.prompt: Try 124 taken 3 times. Build three rows, combine, and exchange if needed. Then try 231 taken 2 times.

slides.text: 'You can now add, subtract, AND multiply with the stamp game! These stamps are very powerful tools.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child perform 3-digit multiplication using the stamp game, exchanging when necessary?

parent_notes: Stamp game multiplication follows the exact same principle as golden bead multiplication: build the number on multiple trays (or rows), then combine. The transition from golden beads to stamps is a step toward abstraction — each stamp represents a quantity rather than physically embodying it. Problems that require exchange are important: 124 x 3 yields 12 units, which must be exchanged for 1 ten and 2 units. If the child finds this challenging, go back to a simpler problem (like 111 x 3 = 333, no exchange needed) and build complexity gradually. The stamp game prepares for long multiplication on paper by making the process of 'carrying' concrete.

title: Europe — Countries and Cultures Continued
description: Deepening the Europe puzzle map work. The child revisits the countries learned last week and adds new ones: Sweden, Greece, and Russia. Brief cultural facts bring each country to life.
instructions:
1. Review: 'Can you find Italy, France, Spain, United Kingdom, and Germany on the map?' Child places these pieces.
2. Introduce Sweden: 'This long country in the north is Sweden. It is very cold there in winter and has beautiful forests.'
3. Introduce Greece: 'This country at the bottom is Greece. The ancient Greeks built amazing temples and started the Olympic Games!'
4. Introduce Russia: 'This HUGE country stretches all the way to Asia! It is the biggest country in the world.'
5. Three-period lesson for the new countries.
6. Share one cultural fact per country (food, landmark, tradition).
7. Child rebuilds the map including all 8 countries.
materials_needed: Pictures of landmarks/foods from Sweden, Greece, Russia

slides.setup_instructions: Set up the puzzle map. Prepare picture cards showing landmarks or food from Sweden, Greece, and Russia.

slides.text: 'Last week we learned five European countries. Can you place them? Italy... France... Spain... United Kingdom... Germany.' Child places each piece.
'Today three more! This is SWEDEN — way up north. Swedish people eat meatballs and celebrate a holiday with candles in their hair called St. Lucia Day!'
'This is GREECE — at the bottom near the sea. The ancient Greeks created the Olympics! And they built beautiful white buildings called temples.'
'And this enormous piece is RUSSIA — the biggest country in the world! Russian nesting dolls (matryoshka) have smaller dolls inside bigger ones.'

slides.prompt: Place all 8 countries on the puzzle map. Match each country to its flag card. Tell me one fact about each country.

slides.text: 'You know 8 European countries now! Europe is full of different languages, foods, and traditions — all close together.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name and place all 8 studied European countries and share a fact about each new country?

parent_notes: Building geography knowledge incrementally — adding a few countries each session — prevents overwhelm and builds lasting memory. Cultural facts make countries memorable: Swedish meatballs, Greek Olympics, Russian nesting dolls. These connections give the child mental hooks for remembering. If you have objects from these countries (a matryoshka doll, a Greek olive oil bottle, a Swedish Dala horse), bring them out as concrete connections. Flags add another visual element. Some children become passionate about particular countries and want to learn more — follow this interest with library books, cooking projects, or music. The Europe map has many small pieces; do not rush to learn them all. Depth over breadth is the Montessori approach.

title: Read-Aloud: Mike Mulligan and His Steam Shovel by Virginia Lee Burton
description: The classic story of Mike Mulligan and Mary Anne the steam shovel, who prove they can dig a cellar in one day. Themes of perseverance, teamwork, and adapting to change connect to the woodworking introduction.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'This is a story about a man and his steam shovel — a big machine that digs.'
2. Read aloud with energy. When Mike makes his promise: 'Do you think they can do it?'
3. As they dig: 'They are almost done! But wait — what is the problem?'
4. After the solution: 'How did Mike and Mary Anne solve their problem? What would you have done?'
5. Discuss: 'Mike and Mary Anne never gave up, even when things looked hard.'
6. Connect to tools: 'Mike used a big machine. You used a real hammer today! Tools help us build.'
materials_needed: Mike Mulligan and His Steam Shovel by Virginia Lee Burton

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.subheading: Mike Mulligan and His Steam Shovel

slides.setup_instructions: Have the book ready. This is a longer picture book — plan for about 15 minutes of reading time.

slides.text: 'Mike Mulligan has a steam shovel named Mary Anne. They have worked together for years. But now everyone wants new machines. Will Mike and Mary Anne find work?'
Read aloud. At the challenge: 'Mike says he can dig the cellar in ONE DAY! Do you believe him? That is a big promise.'
After the problem is revealed (they are stuck): 'Oh no! They dug so well that now they cannot get out! What would YOU do?'

slides.prompt: Draw Mike and Mary Anne digging. Or design your own machine — what would it build? Draw it and tell me about it.

slides.text: 'Mike never gave up, and he found a creative solution. When you work hard and think creatively, you can solve big problems too!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child retell the story's problem and solution and connect the theme of perseverance to their own experiences?

parent_notes: Virginia Lee Burton's classic pairs wonderfully with the woodworking introduction. Both involve real tools doing real work. The story has multiple layers: perseverance, the passage of time (old vs. new technology), creative problem-solving, and the value of loyal partnership. The ending — Mary Anne becoming the furnace of the building she helped create — can be read as either happy or bittersweet, and children often have interesting reactions. The illustrations show the passage of time beautifully, with the town growing around Mike and Mary Anne. This is a book many children want to hear multiple times. Burton's other books (The Little House, Katy and the Big Snow) make excellent follow-ups.

title: Geometric Solids — Bases and Faces Continued
description: Building on the geometric solids introduction, the child explores the properties of each solid more deeply: counting faces, edges, and vertices, and matching solids to their base shapes.
instructions:
1. Review the 5 geometric solids by name.
2. 'Today we look more closely at each solid. Let us count FACES.' Start with the cube.
3. Place the cube on paper. Trace one face. 'What shape is this face? A square! How many square faces does a cube have?' Count: 6.
4. Cylinder: trace the circular base. 'Two circles and one curved surface that is not a face.'
5. Cone: trace the base. 'One circle and a point at the top — that point is called an APEX.'
6. Pyramid: trace the base (square). Count the triangular faces: 4 sides + 1 base = 5 faces.
7. Match each solid to its base shape traced on paper.
materials_needed: Geometric solids (sphere, cube, cylinder, cone, pyramid)

slides.setup_instructions: Place all solids on the mat. Have paper and pencil ready for tracing bases.

slides.text: 'Name each solid as I hold it up.' Review: sphere, cube, cylinder, cone, pyramid. 'Today we become shape detectives — we will discover what each solid is made of!'
'A FACE is a flat surface. Can you find a face on the cube? Put the cube on the paper and trace around it. What shape is the face? A SQUARE!'
'How many faces does the cube have? Let us count by touching each one.' Count together: 6 faces. 'Where two faces meet is an EDGE. Count the edges: 12!'
'Does the sphere have faces? No! It is all curved. Does the cylinder? Two flat circle faces on the ends. And the cone has one circle face and an APEX — a point at the top.'

slides.prompt: Trace the base of each solid on paper. Label each tracing with the solid's name. Count and record: how many faces does each solid have?

slides.text: 'Every solid has special properties: faces, edges, and vertices. You are becoming a geometry expert!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child trace the base shape of each solid and count its faces correctly?

parent_notes: This lesson deepens geometric understanding by introducing mathematical vocabulary: face (flat surface), edge (where two faces meet), and vertex (corner point, plural: vertices; apex for the top of a cone or pyramid). Tracing the base of each solid connects 3D shapes to 2D shapes — the child sees that a cube has square faces, a cylinder has circular faces, and a pyramid has a square base with triangular sides. This is foundational for understanding surface area and nets in later math. The sphere is unique because it has no faces, edges, or vertices — it is entirely curved. Let the child discover this by trying to find a flat spot to trace. If they cannot, ask, 'Why not?'

title: Grammar — The Adjective (Montessori Grammar Symbols)
description: Introduction to the adjective and its Montessori grammar symbol: a medium dark blue triangle. The child discovers that adjectives are words that describe nouns — they tell us what kind, what color, or how many.
instructions:
1. Place an object on the table: 'Bring me a ball.' Child brings it.
2. Place two balls (different colors): 'Bring me a ball.' Which one? 'I need to say MORE! Bring me the RED ball.'
3. 'RED describes the ball. It tells us WHICH ball. Words that describe nouns are called ADJECTIVES.'
4. Present the grammar symbol: medium dark blue triangle.
5. Practice: 'The big cat. The small cat. The fluffy cat.' What word is the adjective?
6. Sentence strips: child places the dark blue triangle above each adjective.
7. Play the adjective game: add adjectives to plain nouns.
materials_needed: Montessori grammar symbols (dark blue triangle for adjective, light blue triangle for article, black triangle for noun)
Two similar objects in different colors/sizes

slides.heading: Grammar
slides.subheading: The Adjective — Medium Dark Blue Triangle

items: Grammar symbols: dark blue triangle (adjective), light blue triangle (article), black triangle (noun)
slides.setup_instructions: Place two similar objects that differ in one quality (color, size) on the table. Have grammar symbols and sentence strips ready.

slides.text: 'Bring me a ball.' Child brings one. 'But I wanted the other one! How do I tell you which one? I say: bring me the RED ball. RED is the word that tells you WHICH ball.'
'Words that DESCRIBE nouns are called ADJECTIVES. Red, big, small, soft, three, old — these are all adjectives. They tell us more about the noun.'
'The adjective's symbol is a MEDIUM DARK BLUE TRIANGLE.' Show the symbol. 'It is bigger than the article triangle because adjectives are important describing words.'
Sentence strip: 'The fluffy cat sat on a soft mat.' 'Find the adjectives — which words describe a noun?' Child places dark blue triangles above 'fluffy' and 'soft.'

slides.prompt: Read each sentence strip. Place symbols above the words: light blue triangle for articles, dark blue triangle for adjectives, black triangle for nouns. Can you find them all?

slides.text: 'Adjectives make language interesting! Without them, everything would be plain: a ball, a cat, a day. With adjectives: a shiny ball, a sleepy cat, a beautiful day!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify adjectives in sentences and distinguish them from articles and nouns?

parent_notes: The Montessori adjective lesson is brilliantly experiential. By asking for 'a ball' when two are present, the child EXPERIENCES the need for an adjective — it is not an abstract grammar rule but a practical necessity. The detective game (bring me the ___ ball) can continue throughout the day. The grammar symbol hierarchy is logical: nouns are large black triangles (the most important words — things), adjectives are medium dark blue triangles (they describe nouns, so same family but different), and articles are small light blue triangles (minor words that introduce nouns). This visual system makes grammar tangible. The child physically places symbols above words, turning grammar analysis into a hands-on activity.

title: Introduction to Fractions — Fraction Circles
description: The child is introduced to fractions using Montessori fraction circles (fraction insets). Starting with a whole circle, they discover halves, thirds, and fourths by fitting the pieces together.
instructions:
1. Present the whole fraction circle (red). 'This is ONE WHOLE circle.'
2. Present the halves (two equal pieces). 'When we cut a whole into TWO EQUAL pieces, each piece is called ONE HALF.' Write: 1/2.
3. 'Two halves make one whole.' Assemble and disassemble.
4. Present thirds: 'Three EQUAL pieces. Each is ONE THIRD.' Write: 1/3.
5. Present fourths: 'Four equal pieces. Each is ONE FOURTH or ONE QUARTER.' Write: 1/4.
6. Mix up the pieces. Child assembles each circle.
7. Compare: 'Which is bigger, one half or one fourth? Let us check!'
materials_needed: Montessori fraction circles (whole, halves, thirds, fourths)

items: Fraction circles: whole, halves, thirds, fourths
slides.setup_instructions: Set out the fraction circles in their frames. Place labels nearby. Work on a clear mat.

slides.text: 'This red circle is ONE WHOLE — one complete circle, nothing missing.' Place the whole on the mat. Label it: 1.
'Now look at this: the same size circle, but cut into TWO EQUAL pieces. Each piece is called ONE HALF.' Remove one half and hold it up. 'It takes two halves to make a whole.'
'This circle is cut into THREE equal pieces. Each one is ONE THIRD.' Show how three thirds make a whole. 'And this one is FOUR equal pieces — ONE FOURTH or ONE QUARTER.'
'Let us compare! Place one half next to one fourth. Which is bigger? ONE HALF is bigger! When you cut into MORE pieces, each piece gets SMALLER.'

slides.prompt: Assemble each fraction circle. Then compare: put 1/2 next to 1/3 next to 1/4. Which is biggest? Which is smallest? Draw the fractions on paper.

slides.text: 'A fraction is a PART of a whole. More pieces means smaller pieces! You will use fractions when cooking, sharing, and measuring.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name halves, thirds, and fourths, assemble them into wholes, and compare their sizes?

parent_notes: Fractions are one of the most challenging math concepts, and Montessori's concrete approach makes them accessible to young children. The fraction circles (also called fraction insets) are color-coded and fit into frames, making them self-correcting — pieces from different fractions do not fit in the wrong frame. The key insight at this stage is that more pieces means smaller pieces: 1/4 is smaller than 1/3, which is smaller than 1/2. This is counterintuitive (4 is bigger than 2, but 1/4 is smaller than 1/2) and needs many concrete experiences to internalize. Connect fractions to real life: cutting a pizza, sharing an apple, dividing playdough. Use fraction language throughout the day: 'You ate half your sandwich!'

title: Animal Classification — Birds (External Parts)
description: A closer study of birds as a vertebrate class. The child learns the external parts of a bird (beak, wings, feathers, talons, tail) and discovers how different beaks are adapted for different foods.
instructions:
1. 'Last week we learned the five vertebrate classes. Today we zoom in on BIRDS!'
2. Present a large picture or model of a bird. Label parts: beak, wing, feather, tail, talon/foot, eye, breast.
3. 'What makes birds special? FEATHERS! They are the only animals with feathers.'
4. Show different beak shapes: 'A hawk has a curved beak for tearing meat. A hummingbird has a long thin beak for reaching into flowers. A duck has a flat beak for scooping water.'
5. 'The beak tells us what the bird EATS!'
6. Match beak pictures to food sources.
7. Child labels a bird diagram.
materials_needed: Part labels: beak, wing, feather, tail, talon, eye

slides.setup_instructions: Display a large bird image. Prepare labels for parts. Gather pictures showing 4-5 different beak types.

slides.text: 'Birds are vertebrates with FEATHERS. Let us learn the parts of a bird!' Point to each part on the picture and name it: beak, wing, feather, tail, talons.
'Look at this feather with the magnifying glass. See the tiny barbs? Feathers keep birds warm and help them fly. No other animal has feathers!'

'Now look at the BEAK. Different birds have different beaks for different foods!' Show pictures: eagle (curved for meat), hummingbird (long for nectar), pelican (pouch for fish), woodpecker (strong for drilling).
'If you see a bird's beak, you can guess what it eats! A strong, curved beak eats meat. A small, pointed beak eats seeds. A flat beak scoops water.'

slides.prompt: Label the bird diagram: beak, wing, feather, tail, talon. Then match each beak picture to the food it eats: meat, nectar, fish, insects.

slides.text: 'Birds are amazing! Their beaks are perfectly shaped for their food. Next time you see a bird, look at its beak and guess what it eats!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child label the main external parts of a bird and explain how beak shape relates to diet?

parent_notes: Montessori zoology explores each animal class in depth through external parts (what you can see), internal parts (skeleton, organs — in later years), and ecology (habitat, diet). Beak adaptation is a wonderful introduction to the concept of adaptation — each species is uniquely designed for its way of life. If you have access to a real feather, the magnifying glass observation is unforgettable: the child sees the intricate barbs and barbules that make a feather both strong and light. Bird watching is a natural extension: set up a simple bird feeder and observe which birds visit and what their beaks look like. Field guides for children (like those by Sibley) make great reference materials.

title: Art — Observational Drawing: A Bird
description: The child draws a bird from observation, studying shape, proportion, and detail. This connects to the science lesson on bird anatomy and develops careful looking skills.
instructions:
1. 'Today we draw a bird! Good artists look VERY carefully before they draw.'
2. Display a picture or figurine of a bird. Study it together.
3. 'What shapes do you see? The body is like an oval. The head is a circle. The beak is a triangle.'
4. Demonstrate drawing the basic shapes first: large oval for body, circle for head, triangle for beak.
5. 'Now add details: the eye, the wing shape, the tail feathers, the legs.'
6. 'Add color — what colors are on this bird?'
7. Child draws their bird, referring to the model frequently.
materials_needed: Bird picture or figurine for reference

slides.setup_instructions: Place the bird reference where the child can see it clearly. Set out drawing materials.

slides.text: 'Artists observe carefully before drawing. Let us look at this bird for one whole minute. What do you notice about its shape? Its colors? Its details?'
'Every bird starts with simple shapes. The body is an OVAL.' Draw a large oval. 'The head is a CIRCLE on top.' Add a circle. 'The beak is a small TRIANGLE.'
'Now connect the head and body with a smooth line for the neck. Add the wing — it is like a leaf shape on the side. The tail feathers extend from the back.'
'Details bring it to life! Add the eye (a small circle with a dot), the legs, and the feet. Look at the reference — how many toes does it have?'

slides.prompt: Draw your bird step by step. Keep looking at the reference picture. When the shape is done, add color. Take your time — there is no rush!

slides.text: Display the drawing. 'Compare your drawing to the reference. You captured the shape of a real bird! The more you practice, the more detailed your drawings will become.'
slides.mastery_check: Did the child observe the reference carefully, use basic shapes to construct the bird, and add appropriate details?

parent_notes: Observational drawing teaches children to LOOK carefully — a skill that transfers to science, reading, and everyday life. Breaking a complex subject (a bird) into simple shapes (oval, circle, triangle) makes drawing accessible and non-intimidating. The child learns that everything can be drawn if you see the shapes within it. Do not correct the child's proportions harshly — instead, redirect attention to the reference: 'Look at the bird again — how big is the head compared to the body?' This teaches self-correction. Connecting art to science (bird anatomy) shows that learning areas overlap — a core Montessori principle. Display the finished drawing alongside the labeled bird diagram from the science lesson.

title: Woodworking — Sanding Wood
description: The child learns to sand wood smooth using sandpaper of different grits. This develops the tactile sense, hand strength, and patience while introducing the concept of preparation in woodworking.
instructions:
1. 'Before we build with wood, we need to make it SMOOTH. That is called sanding.'
2. Present three grits of sandpaper: coarse, medium, fine. Let the child feel each.
3. 'We always start with ROUGH sandpaper to remove the big bumps, then use SMOOTH sandpaper to make it silky.'
4. Demonstrate: hold the wood in one hand (or clamp it). Rub sandpaper along the grain (same direction as the lines in the wood).
5. 'Always sand WITH the grain — in the same direction as the lines in the wood.'
6. Child sands with coarse, then medium, then fine. Feel the difference between each stage.
7. 'Touch it now! So smooth! We could paint or stain this wood now.'

slides.setup_instructions: Clamp the wood piece to the table. Lay sandpaper sheets in order. Place a tray underneath to catch dust. Put on dust mask.

slides.text: 'Feel this piece of wood. Is it smooth or rough? It has splinters and bumps. We will sand it smooth with SANDPAPER.' Let the child feel the rough wood.
'Feel these three sandpapers. This one is very ROUGH — it is called coarse. This is medium. This one is very smooth — fine. We use them in order: rough first, smooth last.'
Demonstrate sanding: 'Go WITH the grain — see the lines in the wood? Sand in the same direction. Back and forth, back and forth.' Slow, even strokes.
'Your turn! Start with the coarse sandpaper. Sand until the big bumps are gone. Then switch to medium. Then fine. Feel the wood between each step!'

slides.prompt: Sand your wood piece with all three grits. Feel the wood after each grit — notice how it gets smoother. When you finish with fine sandpaper, wipe with the damp cloth.

slides.text: 'Feel how smooth it is now! You prepared this wood for building or painting. Clean up the sawdust and put your sandpaper away.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child sand with the grain using three grits in correct order, and feel the progressive smoothness?

parent_notes: Sanding develops the tactile sense (feeling the progressive smoothness is deeply satisfying), patience (it takes time and repetition), and understanding of process (coarse to fine, rough to smooth). Sand WITH the grain — this is a real woodworking principle that produces a better finish. A dust mask is recommended, especially for sensitive children. If sanding indoors, work over a tray to catch dust and wipe with a damp cloth frequently. The three-grit progression parallels the Montessori principle of graded difficulty: start rough, refine, perfect. Some children become meditative during sanding — the rhythmic motion is calming. The finished smooth wood piece can be used in a later project (a painted sign, a small shelf, a toy).

title: Grammar — The Noun (Montessori Grammar Symbols Review)
description: Formal introduction of the noun and its Montessori grammar symbol: a large black triangle. The child reviews articles and adjectives, then learns to identify nouns and mark all three parts of speech in sentences.
instructions:
1. 'We have learned articles (small light blue triangle) and adjectives (medium dark blue triangle). Today — the NOUN!'
2. 'A noun is a NAMING word. It names a person, place, or thing.'
3. Present the large black triangle. 'The noun's symbol is the BIGGEST triangle because nouns are the most important words. Everything has a name!'
4. Play the noun game: look around the room and name everything you see. Each is a noun.
5. Sentence strips: child identifies and marks articles, adjectives, AND nouns.
6. 'The big dog ran.' Place symbols: light blue (the), dark blue (big), black (dog).
7. Child marks 5-6 sentences independently.
materials_needed: Montessori grammar symbols (black triangle for noun, dark blue for adjective, light blue for article)
Objects in the room for naming

items: Grammar symbols: black triangle (noun), dark blue (adjective), light blue (article)
slides.setup_instructions: Have all three grammar symbols available. Prepare sentence strips with article + adjective + noun patterns.

slides.text: 'We know articles and adjectives. Now the BIGGEST word type: the NOUN! A noun NAMES something. Everything you can see, touch, or think of has a name — that name is a noun.'
'The noun's symbol is a LARGE BLACK TRIANGLE — the biggest symbol because nouns are the foundation of language.' Show the symbol.
'Look around! Name things: table, chair, book, window, pencil. All nouns! People are nouns too: mama, friend, doctor. Places: park, school, home.'
Read a sentence: 'The happy girl ate a red apple.' Find the nouns (girl, apple), adjectives (happy, red), articles (the, a). Place symbols above each.

slides.prompt: Read each sentence strip. Place the correct symbol above every word you can identify: light blue for articles, dark blue for adjectives, black for nouns.

slides.text: 'Article, adjective, noun — these three work as a team! The article introduces, the adjective describes, and the noun NAMES. You are a grammar detective!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child correctly identify and mark articles, adjectives, and nouns in simple sentences?

parent_notes: The noun completes the first grammar trio: article (small light blue triangle), adjective (medium dark blue triangle), noun (large black triangle). All three are triangles because they belong to the noun family. The size hierarchy reflects importance: the noun is the core word, the adjective describes it, and the article introduces it. In Montessori grammar, children learn parts of speech through physical manipulation — placing symbols, sorting words, playing games. This is far more effective than memorizing definitions. The noun game (naming everything in the room) makes the concept tangible. Children often become excited about grammar when it is presented this way — 'Everything has a name!' Verbs will come next, represented by a red circle, symbolizing the energy of action.

title: Fraction Circles — Equivalences and Combining
description: The child explores fraction equivalences by discovering that 2/4 equals 1/2, and practices combining fractions by placing pieces side by side to see how many parts make a whole.
instructions:
1. Review: 'Show me one half. Show me one third. Show me one fourth.'
2. 'Watch this: place two fourths next to one half. Are they the same size? YES!'
3. 'Two fourths equals one half. They look different but they are the SAME amount!'
4. 'How many fourths make a whole? Let us check.' Place 1, 2, 3, 4 fourths — the circle is complete.
5. 'How many thirds make a whole? Three thirds!'
6. Challenge: 'Can you make a whole using halves AND fourths together? One half plus two fourths!'
7. Record discoveries on paper with drawings.

items: Fraction circles: whole, halves, thirds, fourths
slides.setup_instructions: Set out all fraction pieces outside their frames. Have paper and crayons ready for recording discoveries.

slides.text: 'Yesterday we learned halves, thirds, and fourths. Today we discover something amazing — some fractions are EQUAL even though they look different!'
'Place one half on the mat. Now place two fourths next to it. Look! They are the SAME SIZE! Two fourths equals one half.'
'How many fourths make a whole? Place them one at a time: one fourth... two fourths... three fourths... four fourths — a whole circle! 4/4 = 1.'
'Here is a challenge: can you make a whole circle using DIFFERENT fraction pieces together? Try one half plus two fourths!'

slides.prompt: Explore! How many ways can you make a whole circle? Draw each way on paper. Can you make a whole with 1/2 + 1/4 + 1/4? What about 1/3 + 1/3 + 1/3?

slides.text: 'Fractions can be equal even when they look different. And different fractions can combine to make a whole. You are discovering the secrets of fractions!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child demonstrate that 2/4 = 1/2 and find multiple ways to combine fractions into a whole?

parent_notes: Fraction equivalence is a concept many older students struggle with because they learned it abstractly. The Montessori approach makes it physical: the child literally sees and feels that two fourths and one half are the same size. This sensory experience creates lasting understanding. Let the child explore freely — they may discover equivalences you did not plan to teach. Combining different fractions to make a whole is early preparation for adding fractions, though we do not use that terminology yet. The child is simply putting pieces together like a puzzle. Drawing their discoveries creates a record they can refer to later and reinforces the visual understanding. Take photographs of interesting combinations.

title: Community Helpers — Builders and Construction Workers
description: Exploring the roles of builders, carpenters, and construction workers. The child learns about the tools they use and the process of building, connecting to the woodworking practical life lessons.
instructions:
1. 'Who builds our houses, schools, and roads? BUILDERS and CONSTRUCTION WORKERS!'
2. Show pictures of construction sites, carpenters, and builders at work.
3. Name the tools: hammer, saw, drill, level, tape measure, hard hat, safety vest.
4. 'A carpenter works with WOOD — like we have been doing this week!'
5. Discuss the building process: design, foundation, frame, walls, roof.
6. Role play: 'Let us build a block tower. First the plan, then the foundation (strongest blocks on bottom), then build up!'
7. 'What would you like to build someday?'
materials_needed: Pictures of construction sites and workers
Toy construction tools or real tools
Paper and pencil for drawing a plan

slides.setup_instructions: Display pictures. Lay out tools for exploration. Have building blocks ready for the construction activity.

slides.text: 'This week you used a hammer and sandpaper — real woodworking tools! Some people use these tools every day. They are BUILDERS and CONSTRUCTION WORKERS.'
'Look at this construction site. Workers wear HARD HATS for safety and SAFETY VESTS so they can be seen. They use many tools.' Name and discuss each tool.
'A CARPENTER works with wood. An ELECTRICIAN connects the wires. A PLUMBER puts in the water pipes. Many workers build ONE building together!'
'Before building, they need a PLAN — a drawing of what they will build. Let us make a plan for our block building!' Child draws a simple plan.

slides.prompt: Draw a plan for a building. Then build it with blocks! Start with a strong foundation. Follow your plan. Is it what you imagined?

slides.text: 'Builders work as a team and follow a plan. They use their hands and tools to create things people need. You are learning to be a builder too!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name several types of construction workers, their tools, and explain the basic building process?

parent_notes: This lesson connects directly to the woodworking practical life work — the child has been using the same tools that professional builders use. Emphasize that building is both a physical skill and an intellectual one — it requires planning, measurement, problem-solving, and teamwork. The design-before-building exercise (drawing a plan first) introduces the concept of architectural planning and connects to math (measurement, spatial reasoning). If possible, visit a construction site (from a safe distance) or watch a time-lapse video of a building being constructed. Children are often fascinated by the transformation from empty lot to finished building. The block-building activity with a plan gives practice in executing a design.

title: Read-Aloud: The Three Little Pigs (traditional version)
description: The classic tale of the three little pigs and the big bad wolf. Themes of planning, hard work, and the value of building well connect to construction and woodworking lessons.
instructions:
1. 'This is a very old story about three pigs who each build a house. Let us see which house is the strongest!'
2. Read aloud with dramatic wolf huffing and puffing.
3. After each house falls: 'Why did this house fall down? What was it made of?'
4. When the brick house stands: 'Why did this house survive? What is the lesson?'
5. Connect to building: 'Just like real builders — the MATERIALS and EFFORT matter!'
6. 'If YOU were building a house, what would you make it from?'
7. Draw or build the three houses with different materials (straw, sticks, blocks).
materials_needed: Straw, sticks, and blocks/bricks for demonstration

items: Straw, sticks, small blocks for demonstration
slides.setup_instructions: Have the book ready. Optionally gather real straw, sticks, and blocks to demonstrate the three building materials.

slides.text: 'Three little pigs leave home to build their own houses. But a wolf is watching! Which pig builds the best house? Let us find out.'
Read with expression. Huff and puff dramatically! After the straw house: 'Why was straw not strong enough?' After sticks: 'Was this better? Why not good enough?'
After the brick house stands: 'THIS house did not fall! Why? Because the third pig worked HARD and used STRONG materials.'

slides.prompt: Build three small structures: one from straw or grass, one from sticks, one from blocks. Which is strongest? Test them! Then draw the three pigs and their houses.

slides.text: 'The lesson: hard work and good planning make something that LASTS. Whether you are building a house or learning to read — doing it well matters!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child explain why the brick house was strongest and connect the moral to their own work?

parent_notes: The Three Little Pigs is a perfect companion to the construction/woodworking theme. The story teaches about material strength, planning, and the value of hard work — all relevant to practical life. Building actual mini-structures from straw, sticks, and blocks makes the science concrete: children can test the strength of each material. This is informal materials science! There are many retellings — the traditional version teaches the clearest moral. For a fun alternative perspective, read 'The True Story of the 3 Little Pigs' by Jon Scieszka (told from the wolf's perspective) to discuss point of view. Children love the dramatic huffing and puffing — encourage them to join in.

title: Trinomial Cube — Introduction
description: Introduction to the Montessori trinomial cube. The child assembles the 27 blocks following the painted pattern on the box, developing spatial reasoning and preparing for algebraic concepts.
instructions:
1. Present the trinomial cube box. 'This is a special puzzle with 27 blocks inside!'
2. Open the box and show the painted pattern on the lid and sides.
3. 'The pattern on the box tells us where each block goes. Let us start with the bottom layer.'
4. Remove all blocks. Sort by color groups.
5. Build the bottom layer using the painted pattern on the bottom of the box as a guide.
6. Build the middle layer on top.
7. Build the top layer. Close the lid. 'It fits perfectly!'
8. Child rebuilds independently.

slides.setup_instructions: Place the trinomial cube box on the mat. Ensure all 27 pieces are present inside.

slides.text: 'This is the TRINOMIAL CUBE. It has 27 blocks that fit together perfectly. It is like a 3D puzzle!' Open the box carefully.
'Look at the pattern painted on the box. The colors tell us where each block goes. Let us take all the blocks out and sort them by color.'
'Start with the bottom layer. The big red cube goes in this corner. Next to it goes this block... Match the colors to the pattern on the box.'
'Layer by layer — bottom, middle, top. Each block has only ONE place where it fits. The colors and sizes guide you.'

slides.prompt: Take out all the blocks and rebuild the cube! Use the painted pattern to guide you. Work layer by layer. When you finish, close the lid — does it fit?

slides.text: 'You assembled 27 blocks into a perfect cube! This puzzle trains your eyes and hands to think in three dimensions.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child assemble the trinomial cube correctly using the color guide on the box?

parent_notes: The trinomial cube is one of Montessori's most fascinating materials. At the primary level, it is presented as a sensorial puzzle — the child matches colors and sizes without knowing it represents the algebraic formula (a + b + c) cubed. The cube contains exactly 27 blocks: cubes and prisms in red, blue, yellow, and black. The pattern on the box serves as a control of error. The child works through spatial reasoning, visual discrimination, and fine motor precision. Do not explain the algebra — the child is preparing for it sensorially, just as they prepared for writing through the metal insets. This material is typically repeated many times, and children often develop deep concentration while building it.

title: Reading Comprehension — Answering Questions About a Story
description: The child reads a short story independently and answers simple comprehension questions: who, what, where, when. This develops the skill of reading for meaning, not just decoding words.
instructions:
1. 'You have been reading so well! Today we practice understanding WHAT we read.'
2. Present a short story (4-6 sentences, phonetic with familiar phonograms and puzzle words).
3. Child reads the story aloud. Help only when asked.
4. 'Now let us think about the story.' Ask comprehension questions:
   - 'WHO is in the story?'
   - 'WHAT happened?'
   - 'WHERE did it happen?'
5. Child answers orally. If unsure, reread the relevant sentence.
6. Introduce question cards: child draws one and finds the answer in the text.
7. Child draws a picture showing what happened in the story.

items: Question cards: who, what, where, when
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare 2-3 short stories the child can decode. Write question cards. Set up a comfortable reading spot.

slides.text: 'Reading is more than just saying the words — it is about understanding the MEANING. Today we practice thinking about what we read.'
Present the story. 'Read this story aloud to me. Take your time and think about what is happening.' Child reads.
'Great reading! Now let me ask you some questions. WHO is in the story? WHAT did they do? WHERE were they?' Child answers orally.
'If you are not sure, look back at the story and find the answer. Good readers reread to check! Point to the sentence that tells you.'

slides.prompt: Read the next story. Then draw a question card and answer it. Can you find the answer IN the text? Draw a picture of the story.

slides.text: 'You did not just read the words — you UNDERSTOOD them! That is what real reading is. Keep asking yourself: who, what, where, when?'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child answer who, what, and where questions about a story they have read independently?

parent_notes: Reading comprehension is a separate skill from decoding. Many children can sound out words perfectly but struggle to remember or understand what they read, especially when they are concentrating hard on decoding. This lesson gently introduces the habit of thinking ABOUT the text. The key questions (who, what, where, when) are the foundation of all comprehension. If the child cannot answer, do not criticize — simply say, 'Let us read it again together and look for the answer.' Rereading is a legitimate and important reading strategy. Keep the stories short and phonetically decodable so the child's energy goes toward understanding, not struggling with unfamiliar words. Drawing a picture of the story is a powerful comprehension check — if they can draw it, they understood it.

title: Fraction Circles — Fifths and Tenths
description: Extending fraction work to fifths and tenths. The child discovers that the more pieces a whole is divided into, the smaller each piece becomes, and explores the relationship between fifths and tenths.
instructions:
1. Review: whole, halves, thirds, fourths.
2. Present fifths: 'This circle is divided into FIVE equal pieces. Each piece is one fifth.' Write 1/5.
3. Count to assemble: '1/5, 2/5, 3/5, 4/5, 5/5 — a whole!'
4. Present tenths: 'TEN equal pieces. Each is one tenth.' Write 1/10.
5. 'One tenth is very small! It takes ten of them to make a whole.'
6. Compare: 1/2 vs 1/5 vs 1/10. 'Which is biggest? Which is smallest?'
7. Discover: 2/10 = 1/5. 5/10 = 1/2. 'More equal pieces means smaller pieces!'

items: Fraction circles: whole, halves, thirds, fourths, fifths, tenths
slides.setup_instructions: Set out all fraction circles. Focus on fifths and tenths but keep earlier fractions available for comparison.

slides.text: 'You know halves, thirds, and fourths. Today we go further! This circle has FIVE equal pieces. Each one is ONE FIFTH.' Show 1/5. Write the label.
'Count as we build: 1/5... 2/5... 3/5... 4/5... 5/5 — one whole!' Assemble the fifth circle. 'Five fifths equals one whole.'
'Now TENTHS — ten tiny pieces! Each is one tenth.' Show how small 1/10 is. 'It takes TEN of these to make one whole circle.'
'Compare!' Lay 1/2, 1/5, and 1/10 side by side. 'Half is biggest, fifth is medium, tenth is smallest. MORE pieces means SMALLER pieces.'

slides.prompt: Can you find equal amounts? Place 2 tenths next to 1 fifth — same! Place 5 tenths next to 1 half — same! What other matches can you find?

slides.text: 'Fractions go on forever — you could divide a circle into 20 pieces or 100! But the idea is always the same: equal parts of a whole.'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child name fifths and tenths, compare fraction sizes, and find equivalent fractions using the circles?

parent_notes: Tenths are particularly important because they connect to the decimal system the child already understands from golden beads and the stamp game. One tenth (1/10) is the fraction equivalent of the base-10 system. You do not need to make this connection explicitly yet, but it will click naturally later. The discovery that 2/10 = 1/5 and 5/10 = 1/2 is an exciting moment — the child sees that fractions that look different can represent the same amount. Let the child explore freely: 'What equals 1/2? How many tenths? How many fourths?' Every discovery the child makes independently is more valuable than one you tell them. Photograph the fraction combinations — children love seeing their mathematical discoveries documented.

title: Animal Classification — Fish (External Parts)
description: Detailed study of fish as a vertebrate class. The child learns the external parts of a fish (fins, gills, scales, tail) and how each part helps the fish survive in water.
instructions:
1. 'We studied birds. Now let us explore FISH — vertebrates that live in water!'
2. Show a large fish image or a real fish (from the market). Name parts: fins, gills, scales, tail, eye, mouth.
3. 'Fish breathe through GILLS, not lungs. The gills take oxygen from the water.'
4. 'FINS help the fish swim — like your arms help you swim! The TAIL pushes the fish forward.'
5. 'SCALES protect the fish like tiny armor. Feel how smooth they are in one direction!'
6. Child labels a fish diagram.
7. Compare: how are fish different from birds?
materials_needed: Large fish picture or real fish
Part labels: fin, gill, scales, tail, eye, mouth

slides.setup_instructions: Display a clear fish image or bring a real whole fish from the market. Prepare labels and diagram.

slides.text: 'Fish are vertebrates that live in water. They have special parts that help them survive. Let us learn what those parts are!'
'GILLS — see these slits on the side of the head? Fish use gills to breathe underwater. Water flows in through the mouth and over the gills, which take out the oxygen.'
'FINS help the fish steer and balance. The TAIL fin pushes the fish forward. Side fins help it turn and stop.' Point to each fin.
'SCALES cover the body like tiny tiles. They protect the fish and help it slide through water smoothly.' If using a real fish, let the child feel the scales.

slides.prompt: Label the fish diagram: fins, gills, scales, tail, eye, mouth. Then compare: how are fish different from birds? Make a list of differences.

slides.text: 'Fish are perfectly designed for water life: gills for breathing, fins for swimming, scales for protection. Every part has a purpose!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child label a fish diagram and explain the function of gills, fins, and scales?

parent_notes: Studying fish alongside birds helps children develop the skill of comparison — noting similarities and differences between vertebrate classes. If you can obtain a real whole fish from a fish market or grocery store, the hands-on experience is invaluable. The child can feel the scales, look at the gills up close with a magnifying glass, and examine the fins. This may feel unusual but is deeply educational. The child learns that gills function like our lungs (extracting oxygen) but from water instead of air. The comparison chart (fish vs. bird) builds scientific thinking: both are vertebrates, both have eyes and mouths, but they breathe differently, move differently, and live in different environments.

title: Music — Pitch: High and Low Sounds with Bells
description: The child explores pitch using Montessori bells or improvised pitched instruments. They learn to distinguish high sounds from low sounds and arrange them in order from lowest to highest.
instructions:
1. 'Sounds can be HIGH or LOW. A bird chirps high. A bear growls low.'
2. Present Montessori bells (or glasses filled with different water levels, or xylophone bars).
3. Strike the lowest bell and highest bell. 'Which is higher? Which is lower?'
4. 'Let us arrange them from LOW to HIGH.' Grade the bells in ascending pitch.
5. Play a game: eyes closed, adult strikes a bell. 'Was that high, medium, or low?'
6. 'Let us play a simple melody going from low to high and back down.'
7. Child creates their own melody by choosing which bells to strike.
materials_needed: Montessori bells (or xylophone, or glasses with varying water levels)

slides.setup_instructions: Set up bells or pitched instruments in random order. Have a mallet ready. If using water glasses, fill to different levels before the lesson.

slides.text: 'Close your eyes and listen.' Make a high sound and a low sound. 'Which was higher? Which was lower? Today we explore HIGH and LOW sounds — this is called PITCH.'
Strike the lowest bell. 'This is a LOW sound. It is deep.' Strike the highest. 'This is HIGH — it is bright and light.' Strike a middle one. 'And this is in between.'
'Can you put them in order from LOWEST to HIGHEST? Listen carefully to each one and find its place in the line.' Guide the grading activity.
'Now play them in order — LOW to HIGH! That is called a SCALE. And back down — HIGH to LOW. You just played music!'

slides.prompt: Create your own melody! Choose any bells and play them in whatever order you like. Can you make a tune that goes UP, then comes back DOWN?

slides.text: 'You can hear the difference between high and low sounds. Musicians use pitch to create melodies — the tunes that we hum and sing!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child distinguish high from low pitch and arrange at least 5 bells in ascending order?

parent_notes: The Montessori bells are the primary sensorial material for musical education. They develop the child's ability to discriminate pitch — a skill essential for singing, playing instruments, and appreciating music. If you do not have Montessori bells, alternatives work well: fill glasses with different water levels and tap them, use a xylophone or glockenspiel, or even use a keyboard. The grading activity (arranging from low to high) mirrors other sensorial grading work (color tablets, brown stair) — the child finds order through careful sensory discrimination. Playing a melody from low to high is a scale (do, re, mi...). Let the child experiment freely after the structured lesson — musical creativity emerges from exploration.

title: Advanced Food Preparation — Vegetable Soup
description: The child helps prepare a simple vegetable soup, practicing cutting, measuring, and cooking with heat supervision. This is the most complex cooking project yet, involving multiple ingredients and a cooking process.
instructions:
1. Wash hands. Review the recipe card together.
2. Wash and prepare vegetables: carrots, celery, potatoes, onion (adult pre-chops onion).
3. Child peels carrots with a vegetable peeler. Cuts celery into pieces. Cuts potato into chunks.
4. Adult heats a pot with olive oil. Child adds vegetables with adult assistance.
5. Add water or broth. 'We need 4 cups — let us measure!'
6. Season with salt and pepper. Stir.
7. Cook for 20-30 minutes (during this time, clean up and do another activity).
8. Taste and serve! 'We made real soup!'

slides.setup_instructions: Adult pre-chops the onion. Wash all vegetables. Set out all tools and ingredients on the counter. Have the recipe card visible.

slides.text: 'Today we make REAL vegetable soup! This is a bigger cooking project with many steps. Let us read the recipe card first and gather everything we need.'
'First, PEEL the carrots.' Demonstrate the vegetable peeler: 'Push AWAY from your body. Watch your fingers!' Child peels 2-3 carrots.
'Now CUT the vegetables into pieces.' Child cuts celery and pre-peeled potatoes into small chunks. 'Smaller pieces cook faster!'
'I will heat the pot — the stove is HOT, so this is a grown-up job. When I say, you can carefully add the vegetables.' Child adds vegetables with guidance. Add broth. 'Now we wait!'

slides.prompt: While the soup cooks, clean up all the cutting tools, wipe the counter, and set the table for soup. When it is ready, taste it — does it need more salt?

slides.text: Serve the soup! 'YOU made this soup from real vegetables. You peeled, cut, measured, and cooked. You are a real chef!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child safely peel, cut, measure, and follow a multi-step recipe with appropriate adult assistance near heat?

parent_notes: Vegetable soup is the culmination of the food preparation progression: from pouring to spreading to slicing to peeling and now to actual cooking. The child does all preparation; the adult manages heat safety. This is not about perfection — unevenly cut vegetables cook just fine and taste delicious. The waiting time while soup cooks is valuable: the child learns patience, and the cleanup during cooking mirrors real kitchen workflow. Making soup connects to Stone Soup (read-aloud from Week 16), community helpers (nourishing others), and science (heat changes food, raw to cooked). Send some soup to a neighbor or family member to practice generosity. This recipe can become a weekly tradition.

title: Grammar — Article, Adjective, Noun Sentences
description: Comprehensive grammar practice combining articles, adjectives, and nouns. The child builds sentences, marks all three parts of speech with grammar symbols, and begins to appreciate how these words work together.
instructions:
1. Review all three symbols: small light blue triangle (article), medium dark blue triangle (adjective), large black triangle (noun).
2. 'Let us build sentences where we can mark every word!' Write: 'The red ball.'
3. Child places symbols: the (article), red (adjective), ball (noun).
4. Extend: 'A small, fuzzy cat.' Mark each word. 'Two adjectives before the noun!'
5. Provide 8-10 phrases. Child marks each independently.
6. Challenge: child writes their own article + adjective + noun phrases.
7. Illustrate favorite phrases.
materials_needed: Moveable alphabet or pencil and paper

items: Grammar symbols: article, adjective, noun triangles
slides.setup_instructions: Prepare 8-10 phrase strips: article + adjective + noun. Have plenty of each grammar symbol.

slides.text: 'This week we learned three types of words. Show me the symbols: article? Adjective? Noun? Now let us use them together!'
'Read this phrase: THE RED BALL. Which word is the article? THE! Which is the adjective? RED! Which is the noun? BALL!' Place symbols.
'Here is a longer one: A TINY BROWN MOUSE. Two adjectives! Tiny and brown both describe mouse.' Place symbols: article, adjective, adjective, noun.
'Your turn! Read each phrase strip and place the correct symbol above each word.' Provide phrases: the big tree, a soft pillow, the old book, a green frog, the sweet apple.

slides.prompt: Mark all the phrase strips. Then create YOUR OWN phrases: pick an article, add adjective(s), and a noun. Write them and mark with symbols. Draw a picture for your favorite!

slides.text: 'Article, adjective, noun — they work as a team to name and describe everything in the world! Next week we will meet a new type of word: the VERB!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child independently identify and mark articles, adjectives, and nouns in phrases, and create their own?

parent_notes: This review lesson consolidates the week's grammar learning. The child should now be able to identify three parts of speech and use the correct Montessori symbols for each. The progression from single words to phrases to sentences follows the Montessori principle of building complexity gradually. When the child creates their own phrases, they are applying grammar knowledge creatively. Some children enjoy making silly phrases (a purple elephant, the tiny dinosaur) — this is wonderful because it shows they understand the structure while having fun. Save the child's phrase strips with symbols — these make a great portfolio piece showing language development. The preview of verbs creates anticipation for next week's learning.

title: Fractions in Real Life — Cooking and Sharing
description: The child applies fraction concepts to real-life situations: sharing food equally, measuring ingredients, and dividing objects. This connects abstract fraction knowledge to everyday experiences.
instructions:
1. 'Fractions are everywhere! Let us find them in real life.'
2. Sharing: 'If you have one cookie and two friends, you break it into THIRDS. Each person gets one third.'
3. Cooking: 'The recipe says 1/2 cup of flour. Show me the 1/2 cup measure.'
4. Measuring: 'Fold this paper in half. Now in fourths. What fraction is each section?'
5. Cutting: give the child playdough or an apple. 'Cut it into fourths. Give me one fourth.'
6. 'What fraction of the day is morning? About one fourth — because there are four parts: morning, afternoon, evening, night!'
7. Go on a fraction scavenger hunt around the house.

slides.setup_instructions: Gather practical fraction materials: measuring cups, paper, playdough, and something to share (crackers, fruit).

slides.text: 'Fractions are not just circles on a mat — they are EVERYWHERE! Let us find fractions in real life.'
'If we share this playdough between two people, each gets ONE HALF. What if three people? ONE THIRD each. Four people? ONE FOURTH each.' Child divides.
'In cooking, we use fraction cups!' Show the 1/2 cup and 1/4 cup. 'Which holds more? Let us measure and check!'
'Fold this paper in HALF. Now fold it in half AGAIN. Open it up — how many sections? FOUR! Each section is one FOURTH of the paper.'

slides.prompt: Fraction scavenger hunt! Find things in the house that show fractions: a pizza cut into pieces, a clock face divided into quarters, a half-full glass of water. How many can you find?

slides.text: 'Fractions are part of everyday life: sharing, cooking, measuring, telling time. You will use fractions for the rest of your life!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child identify fractions in real-life contexts: sharing equally, using measuring cups, and folding paper?

parent_notes: This lesson bridges the gap between Montessori materials and real life — the whole point of the concrete-to-abstract progression. Children who can manipulate fraction circles may not realize that cutting a sandwich in half IS fractions. Making this connection explicit is powerful. Use fraction language naturally throughout the day: 'Eat half your vegetables,' 'It is a quarter past three,' 'Share the grapes equally among four people.' Paper folding is particularly rich: fold in half (2 sections), fold again (4 sections), fold again (8 sections). The child can color each section and count: 'I colored 3 out of 8 sections — that is 3/8!' The scavenger hunt turns the whole house into a math classroom.

title: Grace and Courtesy — Setting a Table for Guests
description: The child learns the proper way to set a table for guests, including placement of plate, utensils, napkin, and glass. This combines practical life skills with the social grace of hospitality.
instructions:
1. 'When we have guests for a meal, we set the table beautifully to show them they are welcome.'
2. Show a place setting diagram: plate in center, fork on left, knife and spoon on right, napkin on left under fork, glass above knife.
3. Demonstrate setting one place. Name each item as you place it.
4. 'The fork goes on the LEFT — the same side as your left hand. The knife goes on the RIGHT.'
5. Child sets a full table for the family (or for stuffed animal guests).
6. Add a centerpiece: flowers or a candle.
7. Practice greeting guests at the door and showing them to their seat.

slides.setup_instructions: Clear the table. Lay out all items needed. Print or draw a place setting diagram for reference.

slides.text: 'Imagine a friend is coming for dinner. We want them to feel WELCOME. One way we show this is by setting a beautiful table. Let me show you how!'
'The PLATE goes in the center. The FORK goes on the LEFT. The KNIFE goes on the RIGHT, with the sharp side facing the plate. The SPOON goes next to the knife.'
'The NAPKIN goes on the left, under the fork — or folded on the plate. The GLASS goes above the knife, on the right side.'
'Now a special touch — a centerpiece! Fresh flowers or a candle make the table beautiful.' Place flowers in the center.

slides.prompt: Set the whole table! Use the diagram to check each place setting. Add a centerpiece. Then practice: greet me at the door and show me to my seat!

slides.text: 'A beautifully set table says: I care about you and I am glad you are here. You can set the table for your family tonight!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child correctly set a place setting from memory and demonstrate welcoming a guest?

parent_notes: Table setting is a wonderful convergence of practical life, grace and courtesy, and geometry (spatial arrangement). The left/right placement of utensils is a genuine life skill that many adults do not know confidently. The trick 'fork has four letters, left has four letters' helps children remember. Using cloth napkins and real dishes (child-safe) elevates the experience and builds responsibility. The greeting practice (opening the door, welcoming the guest, showing them to their seat) is role-played first with stuffed animals or family members. Make this a regular responsibility — the child sets the table for dinner each night. This gives them a meaningful contribution to family life, which builds belonging and self-worth. In Montessori, hospitality is taught as a form of love in action.

title: Read-Aloud: Owl at Home by Arnold Lobel
description: Reading 'Owl at Home' by Arnold Lobel, a collection of five gentle, humorous stories about Owl's everyday adventures including making tear-water tea and being afraid of strange bumps.
instructions:
1. Show the cover. 'This is Owl. He lives alone in a cozy home.'
2. Read one or two of the five stories — 'The Guest' and 'Tear-Water Tea' are favorites.
3. Discuss: 'Why was Owl scared of the bumps in his bed? What were they really?'
4. For Tear-Water Tea: 'Why did Owl want to cry? What makes YOU feel sad sometimes?'
5. Talk about emotions: it's okay to feel sad, scared, or silly.
6. These stories are perfect for cozy reading together.
materials_needed: Owl at Home by Arnold Lobel

slides.heading: Read-Aloud
slides.subheading: Owl at Home by Arnold Lobel

slides.setup_instructions: Have the book ready. Pick one or two stories to read.

slides.text: Cover: 'Owl lives all by himself. He has some funny adventures at home. Let's hear about them!'
Read with gentle humor. Arnold Lobel's stories are quiet and funny at the same time.
Discuss: 'What happened in the story? Was it silly? Was it a little sad? Can something be both?'

slides.prompt: Draw Owl in his cozy home. What is he doing? Making tea? Looking at the bumps in his bed? Being a good host to winter?

slides.text: 'Owl is a little silly and a little wise. Sometimes we are too!'
slides.mastery_check: Can the child retell what happened in one of Owl's stories?

parent_notes: Arnold Lobel's 'Owl at Home' is an I Can Read book with five short stories perfect for read-aloud. The stories gently explore emotions — fear, sadness, hospitality, curiosity. 'Tear-Water Tea' is a remarkable story about allowing yourself to feel sad. This connects to Montessori's emphasis on emotional intelligence and self-awareness.
